Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with more or less straight sides; underside decorated with representation of quadruped walking to right, probably a sphinx or maybe a lion, with unidentified element in front of neck; motif possibly stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; pierced through diameter; glaze gone; pale yellow core of medium coarse texture.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Walking lion and sphinx are highly popular motif depicted on scarabs produced at Naukratis (on the various productions of the “Scarab Factory”, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 27-41, see esp. no. 33 for this specimen). This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A191-193, see especially A191 and A192 for this piece, recorded twice in her typology). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 33)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98 and 100, Type XXVIII A191-192) (entered twice)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.012) (phase 3)
